cells.data:
cap.org  look under cancer protocols

look for :
LVI lymphatic vessel invasion (y or n)
PNI Perineural invasion (y or n)
EPE Extraprostatic invasion (y or n)
Margin Status .. cancer in margin? (length of arc along margin)
SVI Seminal Vesicle Invasion (does it invade seminal vesical) (y or n)

Tertiary 5% or less of total tumor area.

our images .5 microns per pixel
50 slides per patient, 1 or 2 patient sections a day (whole prostate)
10 to 15 slides for needle core biopsy

    
Global vs Local
Start evalutation on 2x*10x or 4x*10 maginification (calculate field of view)
Mostly evaluate gleason score on 10x*20x magnification ( so 200x maginfication). 
Based on this you need to calculate the field of view
mimic pathologist by using same FOV to evaluate local vs global features
Nikon Scope

Programming R:
Try running Rips diagram rather than using the grid. Note the runtime, how much faster/slower is this. 

mclapply being used for bootstrap parallel this uses the hyperthreading cores 

look at large structure as persistence features, reduce glands into points

Use local tissue samples, not TCGA data for the paper. Look at the statistics of biological replicates. We have few fives, so not going to have enough data. 
Multiple ROIs per patient, 

Look at betti 0 and betti 1 separately 

need replicate count validation of nuclei segmentation

——————
Look at root project: topology in 3D

NIS-Elements offers a rich spectrum of mathematical morphology functions (clean, erode, dilate, open, close, smooth), morphologic separation functions, linear morphology functions, fill functions (fill holes, close holes), skeleton functions (medial axis, skeletonize, pruning) and other functions (such as: binary invert, convex hull, contour, skeletonize, homotopic marking, zones of influence, etc.).

0.5 μm per pixel with 20x objective
